5.28.text:
We're living on an island with grey seals
surrounding the cottage.

8.96.text: It's quite interesting at night, when it goes dark, we can't go outside.

13.00.text: There's bull seals rampaging out there, there's fighting,

16.00.text: and we hear all the noises.

17.50.text: Then during the day, we open our doors,

19.80.text: and we can literally have grey seal pups at our feet.

30.72.text: So, this time of year, we're starting to see a lot more activity from the bull seals.

35.90.text: but they're also starting to fight as well.

37.66.text: They'll actually protect areas, and protect harems,

40.30.text: because they're trying to breed with these females.

43.80.text: And that's why all this fighting is occurring.

52.50.text: So grey seal pups are born at about 15 kilograms,

55.40.text: and they'll put about a kilogram a day of weight on,

58.25.text: and after three weeks, they're big animals,

60.60.text: about 45 kilograms in weight, when they're independent.

64.40.text: The female, well, she lactates, in those three weeks,

67.30.text: milk, which is very very rich in fat, about 60 percent fat,

71.90.text: and that's how they can put on this tremendous weight,

73.90.text: for survival in the North Sea.

76.50.text: So the National Trust bought the Farne Islands in 1925,

79.54.text: and since then they've been protecting and conserving this place.

82.43.text: It's such an important place, nationally and internationally,

85.62.text: and we've got to save this place for the future,

87.70.text: and that's what the National Trust are doing.
